entry.title: The Keyboard I Never Wanted
entry.content:
Hello, RSS reader! üëã This post has some bespoke art direction you‚Äôll only see if you view it directly. No hard feelings if you prefer to read here, I just wanted you to know! ‚úåÔ∏è

I used a Logitech K800 ‚ÄúWireless Illuminated‚Äù keyboard for more than a decade. Its keys were soft and comfy. The wireless part made it easy to move around when I switched from a wordy task to an artsy one or vice versa. It conveniently shared a receiver with my mouse. I liked it!

But eventually, the battery stopped holding a charge. Many keys were visibly worn down, some were sticking. So I looked for a replacement, starting with the same brand I‚Äôd had such a positive experience with.

By that time, Logitech (or were they ‚ÄúLogi‚Äù now?) had retired the K800 in favor of their new (at the time) flagship professional keyboard, Craft.

Craft was slick. Craft had a fancy dial.

Craft cost twice as much.

I bought one anyway. The K800 served me so well, and this was its successor!

Sure, the keys were flatter now, and more clicky like a laptop. The battery seemed pretty anemic from day one. The dial was fun, but relegated to volume control since the volume keys tended to stick (on macOS specifically, for some reason).

But switching between devices was easier! And it looked nice on my desk.

So, sunk cost fallacy fully in effect, I convinced myself to like it.

Until one fateful morning.

I sat in my office chair, woke my machine, typed my password‚Ä¶ and felt a single key wobble awkwardly beneath my fingertip.

I gentled lifted the loose keycap, turning it slowly between my thumb and forefinger to inspect every angle. A bit of plastic support on its underside had grown brittle enough to fall apart.

So I contacted Logitech support. I figured it was out of warranty, but surely they‚Äôd have some way to purchase a replacement keycap (or even a set) for a premium product they still (at the time) manufactured and sold.

And after the usual customer service song and dance, they did give me an option.

Exactly one.

Buy a whole new Craft. At full price.

At last, the veil of the sunk cost lifted. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even really like this keyboard,‚Äù I thought to myself. ‚ÄúIt cost more than what it replaced and lasted a fraction of the time. If I‚Äôm going to spend the money, I might as well get something more reliable, something I can repair‚Ä¶‚Äù

Oh no.

I was going to have to research keyboards.

This is not my beautiful hobby

If I wanted something repairable, then it had to be modular. And when it comes to modularity in keyboards, mechanical was clearly the way to go. A whole subculture of enthusiasts supported a thriving landscape of components and vendors.

But all those options were intimidating. Layouts, keycaps, profiles, plastics, printing methods, switches, O-rings, PCBs, lighting, plates, cases, connectivity and firmware options to evaluate, jargon and acronyms to decode, compatibility issues to catch.

And pricing varied wildly. Some builds cost less than a food delivery, others more than a new MacBook, and it wasn‚Äôt always clear why. Materials? Technology? Scarcity? Brand?

It didn‚Äôt help that I lacked nostalgia for any particular sound or feel. My only vivid memory of mechanical keyboards was being distracted by the loud clicks and clacks bouncing off the walls and partitions of shared office spaces. This made evaluating reviews and impressions pretty tough, as they often emphasized an aesthetic experience I‚Äôd rather avoid.

Thankfully, I had some help.

After seeing my plight on social media, two friends reached out with advice:

  • Mark Llobrera posed a handful of initial questions via email, patiently (but enthusiastically) sharing his deep well of keyboard knowledge throughout a lengthy correspondence.
  • Jason Kogler used mechanical keyboards already, but happened to be in the market for a new one around the same time, and our wish lists mostly overlapped. He helped refine and validate my choice.

Big thanks to them for volunteering to educate me!

What I chose

With Mark and Jason‚Äôs help, I picked out a Keychron K2 Max, specifically the hot-swappable model in black with an aluminum frame. (This was last year, there are newer models now.)

Deciding factors:

  • Arrived assembled and functional. I needed a working keyboard!
  • Reasonably priced. I just didn‚Äôt feel confident enough to justify the expense of a premium or boutique brand. (I wanted the mechanical keyboard equivalent of the $200 Yamaha guitar.)
  • Supports the most common, standard, full-size components. (I bought a cheap wrist rest to ease my transition from the lower-profile Craft.)
  • Switches may be ‚Äúhot-swapped‚Äù whenever, no soldering required. (This came in handy right away.)
  • Multiple connectivity options, with easy shortcuts to switch between three devices.
  • No number pad. Based on the dust my last one gathered, I figured I‚Äôd reclaim some desk space.
  • Open-source firmware (QMK).

The ‚ÄúSuper Red‚Äù switches it shipped with were still too loud for me, so I replaced them with TTC Silent Frozen linear switches. The upgrade went as smoothly as advertised, and I‚Äôm really happy with the result: Key presses are far quieter, with a pleasant softness not unlike my K800 in its prime.

I disabled the RGB lighting and haven‚Äôt missed it. As a result, the battery life is astounding: I‚Äôve charged it exactly three times since it arrived seven months ago.

I‚Äôm still using the keycaps it came with, and they are‚Ä¶ fine. I think I‚Äôd prefer the broader face of a more traditional key profile, but I‚Äôve yet to spot a set with the right mix of extras and appearance, in stock at a price point I can justify. Someday!

Soapbox time

So far, I‚Äôm much happier with this keyboard. It‚Äôs quiet, responsive, holds a charge forever. It‚Äôs heavy enough to feel stable, small enough to move around when I want. Easy to take apart, fix, clean or customize. I forget I‚Äôm using it, which was really the goal. Don‚Äôt think, just type!

That outcome is rewarding. Understanding my options (and the associated vocabulary) is empowering.

But I‚Äôm still irritated it was even necessary.

Compared to the gorgeous, personalized, lovingly crafted keyboards I saw hobbyists share through the course of my research‚Ä¶ or even compared to the strong opinions I hold for other tools of the trade (computer mice, drawing tablets, art supplies, software)‚Ä¶ my keyboard needs seem pretty basic.

The truth is, I‚Äôd have happily continued buying the same dependable, reasonably priced, off-the-shelf keyboard every 7‚Äì10 years. And to be fair, I received a few recommendations for less modular brands that might have fit the bill. But my trust has been eroded by the relentless trend toward products (in any category) with increasingly higher costs and lower lifespans.

More and more it seems the only way to avoid sinking money into landfill fodder is to become an expert in every, single, thing. And only if you‚Äôre lucky enough to have the time, money, support system and spoons to do so‚Ä¶ a very tall order, especially these days.

I like to learn. I like to tinker. But the obligation really kills the vibe.

Just putting this out there‚Ä¶

If you‚Äôre involved with a project or product that breaks this cycle and involves (or might benefit from) a web application, get in touch with me or my team. I‚Äôd love to work together.

entry.title: My Favorite Games of 2025
entry.content:
Hello, RSS reader! üëã This post has some bespoke art direction you‚Äôll only see if you view it directly. No hard feelings if you prefer to read here, I just wanted you to know! ‚úåÔ∏è

As much as I enjoy books, comics, music and animation, I find it easiest to write about video games. So instead of an all-encompassing media recap, I thought I‚Äôd focus on my personal favorites of the games I got around to playing this year, peppered with my own illustrations throughout.

Released this year

ENA: Dream BBQ is a first-person narrative adventure that constantly surprised me with its surreal twists and exquisite animation. I‚Äôm very excited for future chapters!

Formless Star is a cozy, top-down, creature-collecting adventure with beautiful character designs and pixel art, irreverent writing and an abundance of heart for such a condensed little adventure. I found the ending quite touching!

Ghost of Y≈çtei‚Äôs story is more straightforward than that of its predecessor, which has pros and cons. On one hand, I didn‚Äôt connect as deeply with this entry‚Äôs supporting cast. On the other, I felt a greater sense of agency in directing Atsu‚Äôs journey from humbler beginnings, with less obvious demarcation between primary and secondary objectives. It was a pleasure to lose myself in this gorgeous impression of 1600s Japan.

Nama Takahashi‚Äôs 2021 release, ElecHead, is an excellent (if occasionally opaque) puzzle platformer. But this year‚Äôs follow-up, √ñoo, really impressed me. I felt that satisfying ‚Äúa-ha!‚Äù moment again and again as I crawled and combusted my way through a colorful and quirky microbiome, never once reaching for a walkthrough along the way.

Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii is the fourteenth (!!) game I‚Äôve played in a series known for mixing emotional, street-level melodrama with unabashedly silly side content. This entry focuses overwhelmingly on the latter, with ‚Äúsubstory‚Äù vibes throughout from moment one of its truly bonkers premise. Where else can I sail a pirate ship to the attract theme from Daytona USA?

Poco is an astonishingly good point-and-click adventure! The character models are goofy and adorable, the painted backgrounds are lovely, the puzzles are just challenging enough, and there‚Äôs even a map and hint system. Demonstrates more thoughtfulness and polish than many longer, higher-budget games I‚Äôve played.

Squeakross: Home Squeak Home might be the best 2-D nonogram game ever? It builds on the foundations of Jupiter‚Äôs Picross games in terms of UI/UX, with many improvements I‚Äôm sure to miss in competing games. The puzzle quality is consistently top-notch, clearly authored by human beings. The decorating features never fully captured my interest, but the creative theming makes for a more memorable (and cozy) experience.

And I‚Äôd be remiss not to mention Tiled Words, my friend (and Cloud Four alum) Paul Hebert‚Äôs letter-shifting crossword puzzle challenge. It‚Äôs been a blast watching this evolve from a rough proof-of-concept into my favorite daily game to help kick-start my brain each morning.

Honorable Mention: ‚ÄúRoguelites‚Äù

Before this year, the only roguelike game I‚Äôd really enjoyed was Balatro. But then I discovered Far Fishing, which led me to Vampire Survivors, then Brotato and Megabonk.

I like the way these games invert traditional ‚Äúbullet hell‚Äù conventions for a play experience that‚Äôs action-packed yet strangely relaxing. And the wealth of incremental items and upgrades makes for an incredibly addictive loop.

As with many addictive things, enjoyability diminishes as the pace of rewards slows down, so I struggle to highlight any one title. But I was entertained enough by the subgenre in aggregate to merit acknowledgement.

(I‚Äôm also enjoying Dogpile, a Suika-like deck builder with appealing, cartoony visuals.)

New to me

These came out before 2025, but I first played them this year.

1000xResist (2024) is a triumph! There‚Äôs a surefootedness to it that‚Äôs remarkable for a team‚Äôs first game. The story is unique and fascinating throughout, the vocal performances are textured and believable, the soundtrack swells at all the right moments. I had literal dreams about this game until I reached its conclusion!

As much as I enjoy Kyle Thompson‚Äôs previous releases (Sheepo and Islets), he really outdid himself with Crypt Custodian (2024). I love the look of it: Characters with stylish silhouettes against lush and moody backdrops. Encounters provide just enough challenge without sacrificing the game‚Äôs surprisingly mellow tone. The UI affordances for telegraphing Pluto‚Äôs relationship to the ground are surprisingly effective: I found myself moving with the confidence of a 3D platformer.

Norco (2022) is a thoughtfully designed point-and-click adventure set in a near-future dystopian Louisiana. Filled with characters that range from strangely endearing to truly repellent, the naturalistic dialog and undercurrent of humor kept me engaged through far more dark and upsetting (but effective and purposeful) story beats than I‚Äôd normally have the stomach for.

Minishoot‚Äô Adventures (2024) (note the apostrophe) overcame my general dislike of ‚Äúbullet hell‚Äù shooters with one brilliant design decision: You retain items and experience between deaths, rewarding both skill and perseverance. Before long, I‚Äôd settled into that cozy Zelda/Metroid exploration flow, wandering a bright and cartoony world, uncovering new skills and secrets, and dispatching a wide array of enemies.

As a longtime fan of Katamari Damacy, I‚Äôm ashamed to admit I‚Äôd never played its direct sequel until We Love Katamari Reroll+ Royal Reverie (2023). While I prefer the original game‚Äôs soundtrack, less frequent banter, and slow ascent to an epic climax, I have to admit these courses are more fun to play and replay. And the postmodern narrative is an inspired choice given creator Keita Takahashi‚Äôs conflicted feelings about directing a follow-up (as described in L.E. Hall‚Äôs wonderful book).

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder‚Äôs Revenge (2022) gracefully iterates on the classic Konami brawlers with an expanded roster, improved controls, an overworld map and fewer ‚Äúquarter-eating‚Äù frustrations. The visuals and audio ooze (pun intended) polish and nostalgia in equal measure.

I tend to dislike survival games, but Loddlenaut (2023) won me over. There‚Äôs just enough danger (managing resources, inventory and oxygen) and mystery (where‚Äôd all this gunk come from?) to keep me engaged but not frustrated. The art and aesthetic are super cute, the controls feel great, the vibes are cozy, and potentially monotonous tasks like cleaning and crafting are just simplified enough to be fun. (If you fondly remember Chao gardens, you‚Äôll probably enjoy the game‚Äôs ‚Äúloddles‚Äù as much as I did.)

Pok√©mon Unbound (2022) is a fan-made, full-game overhaul of Pok√©mon FireRed with its own region, campaign and features. I‚Äôm amazed by how much the presence of honest-to-goodness, substantial side-quests, puzzles and mini-games (alongside many quality-of-life improvements) reinvigorated my love for this decades-old formula.

Revisited

I‚Äôve played all these before in some form or another, but gave them a fresh look in 2025.

Beyond Good & Evil: 20th Anniversary Edition (2024) convinced me to add the game to my all-time faves:

Though not without its flaws, the vibes of Beyond Good & Evil remain so special and distinct. I adore the Mediterranean-inspired environments (canals > roadways), the stylized character designs, the emphasis on exploration, photo¬≠journalism and (approachable) stealth over combat, and Christophe H√©ral‚Äôs eclectic soundtrack. Whether or not its sequel ever escapes development hell, I appreciate this entry more with every playthrough.

I then revisited an earlier effort by the same team on my beloved Dreamcast, Rayman 2: The Great Escape (1999). Each stage fully invests in its theme, with no one mechanic overstaying its welcome. I love the look of the game, too: Organic, hand-painted textures (especially gorgeous in the Dreamcast version) adorn lush forests, damp caves, creaking ships and rusty old factories. Character designs are whimsical, exaggerated and cartoony, the score is swash¬≠buckling and catchy. While not without common issues of the era (camera, audio mix, etc.), it remains a standout in its genre.

I‚Äôm not sure why I didn‚Äôt connect with Papers, Please (2013) the first time I played. Maybe I‚Äôve matured, or maybe Mars After Midnight excited the right synapses, but this year‚Äôs playthrough felt radically better. I lost myself in the rhythm of the gameplay loop, I admired the interface and presentation, I took genuine interest in the story as I retried days to correct mistakes or discover new endings. I found myself looking for, and finding, glimmers of humor and lightness in the gloom.

I went into Sonic X Shadow Generations (2024) primarily for the new ‚ÄúShadow Generations‚Äù content. But I ended up mostly falling back into the core game, thanks to the removal of lives (emboldening me to experiment more with different paths) and much smoother performance (at least compared to the PS3/360 original). These improvements helped me better appreciate Generations‚Äô stage designs, which pay homage to a surprisingly diverse range of Sonic‚Äôs history while standing on their own thanks to some really clever routes, stage-specific gimmicks and exciting set pieces.

After building my custom Game Boy Advance, I ended up replaying four 2-D Metroid games in a row, starting with my GBA‚Äôs visual inspiration and hopping between other titles/consoles from there:

  • Metroid Fusion (2002): Beautiful and chilling
  • Metroid: Zero Mission (2004): All-around approachable introduction
  • Super Metroid (1994): Better every playthrough
  • Metroid: Samus Returns (2017): Underrated

On my radar

My backlog has modestly grown since clearing it this Spring. Games I‚Äôm excited to play include Neva, Venba, Tchia and Haiku the Robot. (I guess I like two-syllable protagonist names ending in a vowel? Weird!)

To keep that backlog reasonable, I held off on plenty of 2025 releases that piqued my interest. I hope to eventually play Promise Mascot Agency, despelote, Pipistrello and the Cursed Yoyo, Kabuto Park, Tall Trails, Sword of the Sea, Henry Halfhead, Consume Me, Dispatch, Skate Story, Sonic Racing: Crossworlds and Marvel Cosmic Invasion. (I‚Äôd also like to check out South of Midnight and Keeper when/if they release for PS5‚Ä¶ they seem too lovely to confine to a handheld or older GPU!)

I‚Äôm sure 2026 will stretch my wishlist even further. TOEM 2, Building Relationships, Hermit and Pig and Big Hops all seem like my cup of tea. I‚Äôm morbidly curious to try a remake of my least favorite Yakuza game and a Bubsy game that might actually be okay.

Or maybe I‚Äôll mostly replay old favorites. Or learn Godot, draw a comic, teach Buster a new trick, tinker with more electronics, pick up the guitar again, try some new recipes. Assuming the world continues to afford me leisure time, I‚Äôll use it as I please. Life‚Äôs too short to succumb to FOMO.

entry.title: Them‚Äôs the Breaks
entry.content:
On the web, it‚Äôs easy to take line breaks for granted.

We get them for free between our headings, paragraphs, list items, <div> elements and more. We display them as-is in our code snippets thanks to <pre>. And most magically of all, our browsers insert breaks automatically where lines of text (or other text-like ‚Äúinline‚Äù elements) would otherwise outgrow their container.

But sometimes, that isn‚Äôt enough.

entry.title: That time Steve Silberman wrote me a nice email‚Ä¶
entry.content:
It was July of 2009. Twitter wasn‚Äôt a cesspool yet, and I‚Äôd released two silly mashups using its API: Portwiture, which built a Flickr mood board from keywords you‚Äôd tweeted, and TweetPlus, which discovered where your friends were blogging.

On a random Wednesday morning, I welcomed this email to my inbox:

Tyler:

I just spent some time tweeting madly about Portwiture (like, almost too much) and then found TweetPlus. I am a contributing editor of Wired magazine, and you are a genius. The UI messages in Tweet Plus are hilarious.

‚ÄúTyler Sticka has built two of the best ‚Äì and most hiply designed ‚Äì applications of the Twitter API in Portwiture and Tweet Plus. He‚Äôs a software poet.‚Äù

That‚Äôs a true thing.

Yay Tyler.

Steve Silberman

We began a brief correspondence. When I asked his permission to include that quote in my portfolio, Steve replied:

Feel free to use that quote, I sent it to you for that purpose if it‚Äôs not too dorky.

When he found a bug in Portwiture and I mentioned some API frustrations:

Dude:

I dig the API issue. You‚Äôre still a genius. You‚Äôre one of the smartest web designers I‚Äôve ever come across, and I‚Äôve been coming across them since 1994.

Hopefully someday we‚Äôll have a coffee. In the meantime, keep it up.

Steve

It‚Äôs hard to overstate how much those messages meant (and still mean) to me. It‚Äôs not like Steve wouldn‚Äôt have been busy: Wired would publish his award-winning article ‚ÄúThe Placebo Problem‚Äù just a few weeks after our chat (Neurotribes arriving quite a while after). His testimonial was featured on my website and r√©sum√© for many years.

Sadly, we never had that coffee: Steve passed away in August of last year. I missed the news at the time, lost in the chaos of election cycle coverage and fragmented social media. An offhand, past-tense reference in my Mastodon feed finally clued me in, prompting me to share this story.

If you like someone‚Äôs work, let them know.

entry.title: My Custom Game Boy Advance
entry.content:
Hello, RSS reader! üëã This post has some bespoke art direction you‚Äôll only see if you view it directly. No hard feelings if you prefer to read here, I just wanted you to know! ‚úåÔ∏è

After a couple years of enjoying my customized Neo Geo Pocket Color, I was ready for another handheld project. This time, I decided to modify an original AGB model Game Boy Advance.

Why?

I own a dozen or so Game Boy, Game Boy Color and Game Boy Advance cartridges, but no console to enjoy them on. (I long ago traded in my GBA toward a DS, then the DS toward a 3DS.)

I considered a modern compatible handheld, such as the Analogue Pocket. But these tend to mimic the vertical orientation of the original Game Boy line‚Ä¶ understandably so, it‚Äôs iconic! But I‚Äôve always preferred the ergonomics of a horizontal layout.

This made an AGB model the clear choice: Horizontal, common, and fully backwards-compatible (unlike a Game Boy Micro or Nintendo DS).

Aesthetic

The Game Boy Advance line sold tens of millions of units, so the selection of aftermarket components is vast compared to that of the cult classic NGPC. To narrow down my choices, I decided to pay homage to the first-party exclusive title I associate most with the GBA, Metroid Fusion. Specifically, I wanted to echo the strikingly alien (almost aquatic?) look of Samus Aran‚Äôs Fusion Suit.

How?

I sourced the donor console from eBay after striking out at local thrift stores. It took a while, but eventually I found a reasonably-priced AGB with plenty of cosmetic scuffs and scratches (easier to see in person than in photos), a few parts in need of cleaning, but no signs of internal damage (water, corrosion, etc.).

The AGB‚Äôs fatal flaw is its lack of a backlight: Fixing that was my top functional priority. A hispeedido display might have been the best option for its integer scaling, but I went with FunnyPlaying‚Äôs product for its approachability. I still consider myself a beginner at this stuff, so the pre-laminated display and purpose-built compatible shells are welcome conveniences.

Once I made that decision, I carefully selected my Fusion-themed components:

  • ‚ÄúYellow‚Äù FunnyPlaying M2 display kit
  • ‚ÄúClear blue‚Äù shell (specifically for this display kit)
  • ‚ÄúLemon candy‚Äù d-pad and A/B buttons
  • ‚ÄúRose red‚Äù triggers (like Samus‚Äôs helmet)
  • ‚ÄúClear black‚Äù sides (like her arm cannon)

I also decided to add a rechargeable battery after noticing the donor console‚Äôs power light sometimes flickered when using NiMH batteries, a problem I thought could worsen with a backlit display or flash carts.

After everything arrived, I disassembled the console, gave various parts and membranes a good clean with isopropyl alcohol and lint-free swabs, and followed the Macho Nacho Productions install guide.

While I avoided any wire-snapping mishaps this time around (üòÆ‚Äçüí®), there were still new lessons to learn:

  • The soldering process went terribly until I discovered my iron wasn‚Äôt heating evenly! I eventually found the cold spots and adjusted my grip to avoid them. Probably time for a replacement.
  • I struggled to apply fresh sticker labels to the transparent shell, only to decide I preferred how it looked without. Thankfully these peeled away with a flexible plastic spudger and a bit of alcohol to remove any residue.
  • Since I already own a few GBA cartridges, I thought I‚Äôd wait to purchase a flash cart. But one of my games refused to boot (even after cleaning) and another had a compelling community patch to fix a few issues, so I caved and bought an Everdrive GBA Mini.

Impressions

This project felt like the exact right difficulty jump for me. While there‚Äôs nothing about the Game Boy Advance play experience as tough to replicate as the Neo Geo Pocket Color‚Äôs clicky thumb¬≠stick, it‚Äôs a more powerful system with more parts to contend with and potential upgrades to consider. This build was challenging but fun.

And I‚Äôm very pleased with the result! The GBA might be the last mainstream console where 2-D, sprite-based games reigned supreme, so it‚Äôs wonderful to admire all that lovely pixel art without finding a lamp or straining my eyes. Its size, weight, orientation and hingeless design give it a comfy, balanced feel. Having the entire Game Boy line playable on actual hardware with modern conveniences is simply delightful. And it‚Äôs so satisfying to see and hold the Metroid Fusion console variant I‚Äôve always wanted but Nintendo never made.

That doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs perfect. The AGB model‚Äôs d-pad is famously mushy, a problem additional mods might have helped. I could have used yellow conductive pads so start/select have the same hue as the other face buttons. There will always be a newer display, more premium shell or better flash cart.

But that‚Äôs fine by me. My custom Game Boy Advance is the same wonderful console that earned its scuffs and scratches over 20+ years of enjoyment, elevated to the best of my present-day ability, budget and whimsy. I can always tinker more if I feel like it.

For now, I‚Äôve got games to play! ‚úåÔ∏è

entry.title: AI Browsers, ad nauseam
entry.content:
If you think Machine Learning and Web Browsing go together like chocolate and peanut butter, congratulations: This is your moment.

Most of the standbys like Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari and (ugh) Brave have integrated some form of AI assistant, with varying degrees of prominence and control. (At a glance, Firefox‚Äôs implementation seems most configurable, Safari‚Äôs seems easiest to overlook.)

But there‚Äôs also been an avalanche of newcomers.

Deta released a beta (a ‚ÄúDeta Beta,‚Äù if you will) of Surf back in December of 2024: It functions more like a notebook than a browser. December was also when The Browser Company revealed Dia, which officially stole focus from Arc by May of this year. (Atlassian liked it so they put a ring on it.)

Perplexity launched Comet in July. Opera stopped sponsoring YouTube ad-reads long enough to release Neon in September. That same month, Fellou, Oeuvre and Genspark all launched their own ‚Äúagentic‚Äù browsers‚Ä¶ just kidding, I made one of those up (the other two are real, though).

And OpenAI couldn‚Äôt buy Chrome, but they‚Äôre totally over it, they aren‚Äôt sure what they ever saw in Chrome, they have their own browser now, its name is ChatGPT Atlas, they went public yesterday so it‚Äôs pretty serious.

Look, browsers are weird right now, and I‚Äôm all for fresh takes in that space. I‚Äôm still using Vivaldi, I‚Äôm thrilled to see continued progress on Servo, and purpose-built options like Horse and Polypane always bring a smile to my face.

So even though I have a certain degree of skepticism toward AI (under¬≠statement of the year), I genuinely want to be as excited for any high-profile browser launch as I was the first time I tried Mozilla‚Äôs weird upstart or read Scott McCloud‚Äôs Google Chrome comic.
